subject or unit description 1: This unit introduces classical and geo-statistical estimation techniques that are used for quantifying mineral resources in the mining industry, covering the stages from mineral exploration to resource modelling and resource classification. Students will use statistical and geo-statistical techniques to create mining resource models and will acquire experience in reporting resources and reserves in line with the requirements of the Joint Ore Reserves Committee (JORC) code. They will also be informed about the importance of modifying factors.
subject or unit description 2: This unit covers rock mass classification systems especially to practical applications of rock mass discontinuity mapping which includes site investigations. It also covers Excavation stability and spans, Rock reinforcement and support, Mine fill design and applications, Coal pillar mechanics and design, Longwall Geomechanics, caving mechanics, Subsidence, Dynamic events such as seismicity, rock bursts, airblasts and slope stability and its instrumentation and monitoring methods. It includes application of numerical methods to mine design and mining methods selection.
subject or unit description 3: This unit provides students with a comprehensive and practical understanding of the range of impacts that mining may have on society and the environment. Broadly, the unit covers the concept of mining and sustainability; responses of government, industry and private firms to the sustainability agenda; environmental management in mining (including water, waste, acid and metalliferous drainage, and mine closure planning); social and cultural issues in mining, and best practice for environmental and social impacts of mining. Students will acquire an understanding of state-of-the-art techniques in environmental management of mine sites as well as being able to identify the major issues and management strategies associated with social/community engagement and impacts, particularly in relation to Indigenous communities in Australia and internationally. Students’ communication and collaborative skills will also be developed in this unit. Students will also be required to participate in fieldwork activities and industry based problem solving.
subject or unit description 4: This unit introduces key concepts of hydrogeology and the importance of groundwater and the role geology plays in understanding, appraising and managing the valuable and hidden resource. The unit will focus on the hydrologic cycle,  recharge-discharge phenomena, groundwater-surface water interactions, aquifer types and their characteristics, groundwater flow, aquifer tests, groundwater quality and contamination, Western Australia groundwater systems, and hydrogeology in mining. A second focus is in Engineering geology and (a) Engineering classification of rocks and soils, elementary rock mechanics and rocks as construction materials, and (b) Engineering geology of tunnels, open excavations, dams, reservoirs, tailings dams, and foundations for buildings and bridges.
subject or unit description 5: This unit provides students with a sound knowledge in geotechnical investigations and testing. It looks at the areas of purpose of geotechnical investigation and testing geotechnical site investigation methods, planning a geotechnical investigation and testing program and laboratory testing methods for soils and rocks, their applications and limitations, and their interpretation. Furthermore students look at Geotechnical parameter assessment. They will be involved in a Geotechnical site investigation project and its management including the writing of a Geotechnical report using the guideline.
subject or unit description 6: This unit covers the concepts in strategic open pit mine planning. With an emphasis on core topics including the development and implementation of mathematical models for ultimate pit limit, open pit production scheduling, waste dump scheduling, and cut-off grade policy, the unit will potentially look into the application of haulage system simulation as well as project evaluation techniques as special topics.
subject or unit description 7: Rock and soil slope engineering covers the basic mechanics and kinematics of rock and soil slope failure. Initially, discontinuity and rock mass shear strength are introduced, following which the fundamentals of stereographic projection techniques are covered prior to an assignment-based study of data collection techniques. Slope failure mechanisms and limit equilibrium and numerical analysis follows as a basis for pit slope design and the associated economic and construction technique evaluations. Finally, slope support, reinforcement and monitoring are reviewed through both theory and case-study discussions.
subject or unit description 8: Students are introduced to numerical methods and its application for mining engineering, principle of energy method and numerical solution and structural analysis in earth structures. The unit also provides a brief review of numerical methods, selection of numerical application and their modelling procedures. Students will work on a numerical project.
subject or unit description 9: In this unit students are introduced to new techniques for mine development and production, along with new haulage and conveyance systems, mine automation and monitoring. Students will review and evaluate new developments in underground mining systems to achieve productivity, enhance safety and reduce costs. Design considerations for various mining methods will be explored including primary and secondary development excavation design, blast design, cost and productivity estimates, stope services design and materials handling. Geomechanical evaluation and rock properties will be examined along with the application of numerical modelling and limitation and the design methods for dimensioning stopes and pillars. Students will look at the scientific and engineering approach to mine design and will delve into future trends in automated high productivity mining schemes. The emphasis of this unit will be on design principles and discussion of case studies, to illustrate applications of the core principles within the design process.
subject or unit description 10: This unit provides an introduction and assumptions of continuum media, mathematical review, vector, tensor, Eigen value, matrix algebra, State of stress at a point, equilibrium equation, deviatoric stress, octahedral stress, strain at a point, Lagrangian and Eulerian transformation, deformation, compatibility equation and stress strain relationship, linear elastic, non-linear elastic. Students also learn about the elastic relation for solids using deformation, compatibility and stress equations, plasticity, yield surface, yield criteria, flow rules, Characteristics of discontinuous media and compatibility equations, Fracturing (rock fracture mechanics), Flow rules in discontinuum media and Constitutive equation for discontinuum media

subject or unit description 1: Compressible and incompressible flow in pipes; Choked flow; Gas/Liquid flow; Flow patterns in horizontal pipes; Energy loss calculation; Vertical flow; Fluid and particle system; Single particle in a fluid; Multiple particles systems; Porous flow; Introduction to the properties of porous media; Concurrent and Counter-current flow; Filtration; Introduction to filtration process; Incompressible and compressible cake; Filtration equipment Theory of sedimentation; Batch and continuous settler design; Flocculation; compression; settling of drops and bubbles; Fluidisation; Liquid-solid, Gas-solid systems; Centrifuge and Cyclone design  Slurry transport; Pheumatic transport
subject or unit description 2: This unit will cover three important Metallurgical Engineering concepts - kinetics, interfaces and electrolyte. Kinetics determines the rate of reactions such as leaching, roasting and precipitation used in Process and Resource Engineering. While this unit gives an introduction to homogeneous kinetics, activation energy, collision and transition state theories, these will be developed and applied to heterogeneous kinetics in future units. Interfaces are important in the study of flotation, ore wetting, solvent extraction, etc. Specifically, surface tension, gas-liquid and liquid-liquid interfaces, adsorption of gaseous and soluble species on solids, solid-liquid interfaces and three phase systems will be studied. Electrolytes are important in Process and Resource Engineering as they influence the efficiency of electrowinning, leaching, liquid-liquid separation and many other processes. The importance of electrolytes will be examined focusing on ionic interactions and activities including the concepts of conductance of electrolytes and transference numbers.
subject or unit description 3: This unit introduces the main technologies and techniques currently used for mineral processing in the mining industry. Students will gain a conceptual understanding of mineral processing by applying various terms and principles to extractive metallurgical processes, and will learn about the key role that mineral processing plays in the mining value chain and how mining practices can impact on processing outcomes. They will be introduced to three overarching processes: the comminution and liberation of minerals; the separation of minerals; and, the extraction of metals, including emerging approaches, technologies and digital applications in these areas. The unit will enable students to specify appropriate methods for processing a variety of ore types, as well as the relevant underlying phenomena involved. Sustainability issues will be examined, ranging from energy consumption to environment considerations, and safety risks associated with mining processing operations, as well as factors impacting efficiency and cost of the processing system. Students will also have the opportunity to develop their academic and professional communication skills through exposure to, and application of, terms and principles relevant to extractive metallurgical processes.
subject or unit description 4: The chemistry and engineering aspects of hydrometallurgical unit processes - leaching, separation, extraction and recovery. Extraction techniques will include the oxidative and non-oxidative leaching of minerals, purification and recovery of metals by precipitation, ion exchange and solvent extraction. Recovery of metals by reduction and electrowinning. Chemistry, design and operation of some common hydrometallurgical processes.  This unit has on-site laboratory requirements.
subject or unit description 5: Introduction to mineralogy as applied to mineral processing. Elementary crystallography, crystal structures, polymorphs and crystal chemistry including solid solution in minerals. A detailed study of the principal ore minerals including native metals, sulphides and oxides. Trace and minor elements in ore minerals with particular reference to economically important trace constituents. For example, refractory gold in sulphides, and deleterious elements (toxic heavy metals in sulphides), Mineralogy of the more common ore deposit types (gold, PGE, base metals and Fe-Ti oxides) with emphasis on mineral processing, zoning in ore deposits, mineral textures and liberation. Instrumental methods applied to mineralogy including reflected light microscopy, x-ray diffraction, x-ray fluorescence, scanning electron microscopy, electron and ion microprobes. Some discussion will also be made introducing the relevance of process mineralogy into the discipline of geometallurgy.
subject or unit description 6: Metallurgical Material and heat balances. Metallurgical Thermodynamics - fundamental and applications. Metallurgical kinetics.
subject or unit description 7: This unit examines the effect of mineralogy on mineral processing, including liberation models, comminution circuit operations and equipment, as well as unit operations and equipment designed for mineral beneficiation, including gravitational, magnetic and electrostatic separation of minerals. Pulp rheology, electrokinetics and flotation phenomena are considered, as well as advanced topics in bulk solids handling, solid-liquid separation, online sensors and ore sorting.
subject or unit description 8: An overview of some economic techniques used in the analysis of natural resources. It considers some fundamental areas of mineral economics and the mineral economy in Australia. It then uses standard economic concepts, theories and analysis to enhance appreciation of selected natural resources issues. The relationship of non-renewable resource extraction to the economic development process is presented. An emphasis is placed on understanding why natural resources pose particular analytical and policy problems, and on illustrating the contribution that economic analysis can make to the solution of these problems.
subject or unit description 9: The unit covers the financial management and project evaluation techniques of Mineral and Energy Technologies. The unit is designed to provide a basic understanding of the fundamental concepts and principles that influence investment and financing decisions of mining projects at the pre-feasibility stage. Its main objective is to impart to the participants the skills necessary to construct a realistic Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) model of a mining project and to evaluate it initially under assumed certainty and then analysing and taking the related project and financial risks into consideration in shaping investment decisions under uncertainty.
subject or unit description 10: Principles and practice of extractive metallurgical process and plant design at pre-feasibility level of complexity. It includes process selection, process development and optimisation including energy and mass balances, development of process flow diagram, plant equipment selection and plant layout, cost estimation and economic evaluation, environmental impact assessment, consideration of sustainability and social impact issues, development of occupational health and safety plan, and preparation of a process and plant design report.

subject or unit description 1: This unit introduces the fundamental geomechanics knowledge and its application to Mining (geo-engineering) projects. This includes the basics of geo-material (intact rock, rock masses and soil) characteristics and its effect on mechanical behaviour, stress-strain, strength-deformation and failure criteria, time dependency and their application in geo-engineering (Mining, Civil, Energy) projects.
subject or unit description 2: This unit presents a systems approach to the principles, design and application of the major surface and underground mining methods together with the associated equipment, services and infrastructure. The aim of this unit is to provide students with the capability to select the appropriate mining method, together with its associated equipment, services and infrastructure, for a given deposit. The unit covers principles of systems engineering, mine services and infrastructure, surface mining methods (method selection, strip mining, open-pit mining, high-wall mining, solution mining, surface miners and other mining methods), and underground mining methods (mine access and development, long-wall coal mining, thick-seam coal mining, bord and pillar coal mining, underground metalliferous mining method selection, room and pillar mining, cut and fill mining, sublevel stoping, narrow vein mining, caving methods).
subject or unit description 3: This unit covers the principal methods of rock breakage used in mining including machine mining, drilling and blasting. Machine mining encompasses rock cutting principles, cutting with picks and discs, the design of cutter heads, effect of wear, assessment of rock cut ability, impact breakage and ripping. Drilling encompasses the methods of drilling used in mining and the impact of drilling parameters on performance and selection and costing of drilling equipment. Blasting encompasses the chemistry of explosives and mechanics of explosive-rock interaction, selection of commercial explosives, explosive charging techniques, initiation and delay systems, blast design principles for surface and underground mines, safety, environmental and regulatory management and blast performance assessment and analysis.
subject or unit description 4: There are two parts in this unit. The first part covers basic Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) and its application in mining engineering. The second part covers ventilation theory and underground mine ventilation design.

subject or unit description 1: This unit provides a clinical reasoning framework that integrates theoretical constructs of clinical practice with the most current evidence-based practice. Development of neuromusculoskeletal assessment and intervention skills at an advanced level for spinal and some peripheral disorders. Concepts of diagnosis and classification of musculoskeletal disorder within the scope of physiotherapy practice at an advance level. Principles of integration of exercise prescription and self-management in treatment programs, and evaluation of treatment outcomes.
subject or unit description 2: At an advanced level this unit reviews structural and applied anatomy, and pathology of the vertebral column and peripheral regions, relevant to musculoskeletal physiotherapy. The content includes consideration of anatomical adaptations with respect to function, the impact of pathology on function, responses to injury, healing and repair processes in musculoskeletal structures, and how these may be influenced by physical treatment. Pathology, clinical features and diagnostic methods related to disorders commonly presenting in musculoskeletal physiotherapy practice is also covered.
subject or unit description 3: Supervised clinical practice with an emphasis on the development of advanced diagnostic and patient/client management skills in musculoskeletal physiotherapy practice. Development of an evidence-based approach to physiotherapy practice through the synthesis of clinical experience and knowledge of the current evidence.
subject or unit description 4: Preparation and presentation of a project proposal relevant to a specific area of physiotherapy. During this process; literature is reviewed, appropriate research methodology and statistical analyses are chosen to answer a project question and ethical issues are identified. Data management and quality control is evaluated.
subject or unit description 5: Supervised clinical practice with an emphasis on the development of advanced competencies in musculoskeletal physiotherapy practice. Emphasis on advanced skills in patient/client communication, physical examination, interpretation of clinical information and development of evidence-based physiotherapy treatment plans. Evaluation of response to treatment and modification of treatment at an advanced level. Understanding of the indications for inter-professional patient/client referral and inter-professional management consistent with advanced practice in musculoskeletal physiotherapy.
subject or unit description 6: This unit builds on the Physiotherapy Research Proposal Unit and will include the process of data collection, statistical analyses, preparation of results and a discussion that is appropriate for the specific project. Students will prepare, present and submit a project report relevant to physiotherapy.
subject or unit description 7: Development of advanced examination and treatment skills in musculoskeletal physiotherapy practice. Development of patient education and physical management programs at an advanced level, including exercise prescription.
subject or unit description 8: An interdisciplinary approach to the management of pain disorders aimed at encouraging professional collaboration. The focus of the unit is the pain experience of patients and the physiological, psychosocial, and environmental components of that experience, with an application of profession-specific theoretical frameworks to assess and manage pain and disability.

subject or unit description 1: This unit provides a comprehensive preparation for students undertaking research at Masters level and beyond. Students will develop and apply the research skills and knowledge which are key to successful research, in a discipline-scientific context. Students will explore the scientific method and associated behaviours, the nature of research and development, OHS and risk management, research ethics, the location and critical review of scientific literature, the creation and defence of arguments, various research methodologies, presentation of research data, research strategies and the dissemination of research findings. A range of discipline-specific topics are also presented.
subject or unit description 2: The students must study and follow and Agile Software Engineering process in the design, implementation and testing involved in a software project.  Students will work in groups of 4 to 5 and each group will go through three iterations.  Each iteration will involve selecting the functionality to implement for that iteration in consultation with the client and then designing, implementing and testing the implementation for that iteration.   At the end of each iteration, each group must report their progress through an oral presentation and software design artefacts.
subject or unit description 3: A major computing project, selected in consultation with an academic staff member.
subject or unit description 4: Individual projects to be defined in a project proposal jointly agreed by the students and the supervisor.
subject or unit description 5: Introduction to the basic concepts of cryptography with an emphasis on coding theory, classical cryptosystems and public key cryptography. The principles of information theoretic security, computational hardness, number theory (Euclid’s algorithm, Euler and Fermat’s theorems). Public and private-key encryption, message authentication and digital signatures.
subject or unit description 6: Issues and constraints, from a security perspective, of data and services management in cloud computing. Issues such as security of software and the encryption, user resource and request tracking and analysis in a cloud environment.
subject or unit description 7: A detailed examination of software development from the point of view of the industry standard for information security - ISO27000. How to make large scale distributed software more secure and how operating systems are positioned from the point of view ISO27000. How to handle improve distributed data access and communication through various approaches, such as encryption and anomaly discovery.
subject or unit description 8: An introduction to human computer interfaces, including the motivation and contexts for using these. The class teaches a process for user centred development as well as different measures for evaluation and models that inform human computer interface design. Social issues influencing human computer interface design and use are considered, as well as multi-cultural interaction and communication in order to accommodate human diversity. The different user interface standards and principles of graphical user interfaces are covered in addition to designing and programming GUIs both in native and web formats and widgets. Geometry management, event management and user interaction are introduced. Finally, user interface programming environments and future developments are discussed.
subject or unit description 9: An in-depth examination of unit, integration and system testing and the maintenance of large software-based systems. Topics include automated and manual techniques for generating and validating test data, the testing process, static vs. dynamic analysis, functional testing, inspections, and reliability assessments. Testing approaches based on graph theory, finite-state machines, formal specifications, logic and syntax based testing. Testing of graphical user interfaces, Stress testing. Development of a software configuration management plan encompassing tool selection, identification of artefacts, baseline and change control, measurement, auditing and reporting and release of deliverables. To provide practical knowledge of a variety of ways to test software, an understanding of some of the tradeoffs between testing techniques, and a feel for the practice of software testing.
subject or unit description 10: This unit introduces students to Distributed Computing and its associated complexities. Topics covered include remote procedure calls and asynchronous calls, Multi-tiered architectures for distributed computing and XML serialisation and passing objects by value over the network. In addition the unit covers Serverside Web scripting with CGI based approaches. Further topics include Service oriented architectures, Web services as a SOA Framework and modern Internet applications with Ajax and Web Services.

subject or unit description 2: This unit equips students with methodologies for analysing and managing complex software projects, and their ethical challenges. Students learn estimation, scheduling and risk assessment techniques in order to derive project plans, and project management tools in order to help implement them. The unit also incorporates approaches to organisational change management, software quality assurance, release and configuration management, and the dynamics of teams, in order to sustain and manage software projects as they progress.
subject or unit description 3: This unit equips students to develop and communicate complex object oriented (OO) design structures for a given set of software requirements. The unit focuses on selected polymorphic design patterns to impart a set of techniques for creating highly cohesive and loosely-coupled designs. It takes students from high-level Unified Modelling Language (UML) design notations to their practical implementation in OO programming languages. Students also learn about the Model View Controller (MVC) architecture to help promote separation of concerns, containers and generics to promote design reuse, and factories and dependency injection to help address design testability.
subject or unit description 4: This unit explores DevOps practices for integration of the development and operational use of software, and in particular incorporating software security practices (SecDevOps) into this framework. Students are equipped to adapt tools and methods for continuous integration, continuous delivery and provisioning infrastructure-as-code to software projects, and the challenges and opportunities this presents to securing the resulting software.
subject or unit description 5: This unit equips students to evaluate architectural problems and solutions in software engineering, and to develop highly extensible designs to help implement them. Students learn advanced design structures for multithreading in object oriented languages, the use of build systems and notations for creating modular software, the design and implementation of application programming interfaces (APIs), plugin systems and domain-specific languages (DSLs) for fostering communities of developers, and approaches to integrating different languages to combine their different respective benefits.
subject or unit description 6: This unit prepares students to develop complex software requirements specifications, by eliciting key information from stakeholders, using a variety of techniques, tools and notations. Students learn how to gather requirements and how to express them with the clarity and precision needed for the success of a software project. Students also examine the role and scope of prototyping, and requirements gathering and specification in general, in the software development process.
subject or unit description 7: Explores the use of modern client-side and server-side application frameworks for development of sophisticated web applications. The unit first covers in-depth how to work within client-side frameworks to develop complex, usable and high-performance application front ends. Second, the unit discusses and explores back-end technologies for securely implementing server-side business logic and data storage.
subject or unit description 8: This unit explores the challenges of high-performance computing and big data from a software engineering perspective. Students learn how to develop, analyse and optimise software performance at a large scale, the architectural issues entailed in software that utilises very large datasets, and the ethical and compliance issues that arise when these datasets are derived from individuals’ personal details or other sensitive sources.
subject or unit description 9: The most common threats to a system ranging from organised attacks to viruses and malware. This unit provides the knowledge needed to handle these threats with a focus on major network threats and vulnerabilities to an enterprise network as well as covering detailed knowledge of computer forensics (both approaches and tools) for Linux/Windows. Approaches used in massed network attacks and evaluate the methods to address these types of attacks. The basis of viruses and malware and security deficiencies that are typically exploited by viruses and web based malware. In the last part of the unit, the students will cover in detail the tools available under Windows and Unix based systems to detect and trace hacking attacks.
subject or unit description 10: A detailed examination of software development from the point of view of the industry standard for information security - ISO27000. How to make large scale distributed software more secure and how operating systems are positioned from the point of view ISO27000. How to handle improve distributed data access and communication through various approaches, such as encryption and anomaly discovery.

subject or unit description 1: This unit provides a comprehensive preparation for students undertaking research at Masters level and beyond. Students will develop and apply the research skills and knowledge which are key to successful research, in a discipline-scientific context. Students will explore the scientific method and associated behaviours, the nature of research and development, OHS and risk management, research ethics, the location and critical review of scientific literature, the creation and defence of arguments, various research methodologies, presentation of research data, research strategies and the dissemination of research findings. A range of discipline-specific topics are also presented.
subject or unit description 2: This unit introduces the fundamentals of fortran, including arithmetic computations, control structures, formatted input/output, array processing, user defined functions, subroutines, and modules. It also covers numerical methods for solving various mathematical problems, including systems of linear equations, nonlinear equations, interpolation, and integration.
subject or unit description 3: This unit will cover the probabilistic framework for modelling real world processes. Students will acquire practical skills in developing probability models for processes, compute various probabilities of interest and estimate parameters of the underlying models. There will be a particular emphasis on mathematical statistical techniques and how these are used to compute probabilities of interest for both discrete and continuous processes.
subject or unit description 4: This unit introduces key concepts and activities in the areas of logistics and supply chain management and establishes the distinct role each plays in industrial modelling and optimisation. Basic skills in analysing, classifying and solving the fundamental components of inventory systems are developed using both single and multi-commodity deterministic and stochastic models. Forecasting techniques and practices are introduced. Case studies are used to highlight and expand the understanding and application of the topics discussed in the unit.
subject or unit description 5: In this unit we will explore finite difference and finite element methods used widely in applied mathematical modelling and engineering problems.  These techniques include derivative approximation, SOR and ADI methods, explicit and implicit methods - variational statements, finite element formation of elliptic and time-dependent problems, two- dimensional elements calculations, solution of sparse systems of linear equation (sparse matrix methods and conjugate gradient methods) and finite element applications.  You will apply these techniques to design and test mathematical models applied to real-world problems.
subject or unit description 6: This unit introduces the fundamental techniques and methods for solving real world problems by building mathematical models and fosters a deeper understanding of the use of mathematics in science and engineering disciplines. Topics selected from areas of interest to staff members or visiting staff member of the school. For example, chaos, complex systems, heat transfer, fluid dynamics, geomechanics, transform theory, and their applications.
subject or unit description 7: This unit will consider problems arising in business and industry. The students will learn the necessary skills to model and solve such problems through mathematical modelling and operations research techniques with a focus on using variables. The topics covered include: Industrial Modelling: In this part of the unit, several binary and integer examples of mathematical models will be presented and analysed. Dual Simplex Algorithms: the Simplex and the Dual Simplex Algorithms used for linear programming problems will be revised and analysed from a different perspective. Their features will be thoroughly investigated. This part is crucial to the development of the second part of this unit, i.e., Integer Linear Programming. Integer Linear Programming: The Simplex Algorithm and the Dual Simplex Algorithm studied in the first part of the unit will be used as the building blocks of more complex algorithms to solve Linear Programming Problems where all or some of the variables are constrained to be integer. Two methods will be presented: the Gomory Cuts and the Branch-and-Bound Algorithms. Branch-and-Bound Algorithms: In this part of the subject, Branch-and-Bound algorithms will be addressed from a more general perspective, to the end of solving other Integer Linear Programming problems, including the Knapsack Problem 0-1
subject or unit description 8: The unit focuses on 4 core topics in network optimisation: minimum-cost flow problems, optimal fleet sizing, arc routing problems, and node routing problems. For minimum-cost flow problems, areas covered include the standard problem formulation, shortest path problems, maximum flow problems, transportation problems, assignment problems, and the network simplex algorithm. For optimal fleet sizing, areas covered include deterministic and stochastic formulations, left and right derivatives, convex analysis, and the golden section method. For arc routing problems, the areas covered include the Chinese postman problem, Fluery's algorithm, Floyd-Warshall algorithm, matchings, and Euler tours. Finally, for node routing problems, the areas covered include the travelling salesman problem, heuristic methods and lower bound techniques.
subject or unit description 9: The planning, execution and reporting of a suitable applied research project, related to the advanced coursework undertaken by the student.
subject or unit description 10: The aim of this unit is to provide the skills needed to effectively tack the range of planning and management decisions that arise in manufacturing systems. A key objective of a manufacturing system is the timely production of products that conform to the specifications while minimising costs. Different types of manufacturing systems will be studied, including single machine schedule, parallel machine schedule, and job-shop flow.

subject or unit description 6: This unit will introduce students to different aspects of statistical modelling, estimation, and inference. Generalized linear modelling (GLM) extends Normal linear model theory to encompass distributions from the exponential family of distributions, including binomial (logistic regression) and Poisson distributions (loglinear models). Analysis of GLMs will also include formulation, estimation, model selection, diagnostic-checking, and evaluation of predictive ability. GLM will be extended to include extreme value theory and distributions. In time series analysis, the focus shifts to the analysis of data collected or observed sequentially in time. Students will be introduced to the modelling of different types of time series using autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA) models. Topics to be covered include exploratory data analysis, identification of ARIMA models, estimation, diagnostic checking, and forecasting.
subject or unit description 7: This unit will cover survival models, lifetime distributions, statistical models of transfer between multiple states, binomial and Poisson models of mortality, maximum likelihood estimation of transition intensities, age specific transition intensities, statistical tests, standard life tables, and graduation of crude estimates.
subject or unit description 8: This unit will cover the probabilistic frame work for developing stochastic models for real world process with emphasis on actuarial model. Students will acquire practical skills in developing mathematical models for processes, compute various probabilities of interest and estimate parameters of the underlying models. Topics covered include Markov chains and their application to experience rating; Markov process models with application to survival; sickness and marriage models; and simple simulation models.
subject or unit description 9: This unit develops the student’s understanding of the fundamental concepts of financial mathematics, and how these concepts are applied in calculating present and accumulated values for a stream of cashflows. Practical, hands-on modelling experience is developed through the use of EXCEL spreadsheets (students are assumed to have functional EXCEL skills prior to commencement of this unit).
subject or unit description 10: This unit introduces some fundamental theories and methods for the solution of differential equations and multivariable integral and vector calculus problems. It aims for students to develop their mathematical skills for modelling and solving real world problems by using differential equations and multivariable calculus. Topics covered include first-order differential equations, second and higher order constant coefficient linear equations, power series solutions, Fourier series, partial differential equations, gradient and directional derivatives, maxima and minima, double and triple integrals, line and surface integrals, div and curl, path independence, Green’s theorem, divergence theorem and Stokes theorem.

subject or unit description 2: This unit will study oil exploration geophysics, seismic wave types and elastic theory. Well logging, refraction and reflection will also be covered. The field trips and laboratory exercises within the unit are designed to develop competence in acquisition, processing and interpretation of seismic and well log data.
subject or unit description 3: Electrical methods - principles and applications of DC resistivity, IP and complex resistivity, spontaneous potentials and electric well logging. Field trips and laboratory exercises are designed to develop competence in acquisition, processing and interpretation of electric data.
subject or unit description 4: This unit provides a comprehensive preparation for students undertaking research at Masters level and beyond. subject or unit description 5: Environmental geophysics will focus on linking geophysical methods with environmental, hydrogeological or archaeological sciences. Lectures will cover electrical, electromagnetic and acoustic properties of soils, rocks and groundwater. They will also cover application of geophysical methods for groundwater management in a range of industrial and environmental settings such as; mining, agriculture, water supply, managed aquifer recharge and management of the saline water interfaces along coastal margins. Attention will be given to electromagnetic (airborne, surface and downhole), ground penetrating radar (GPR), radiometric, shallow seismic and magnetic surveying for environmental applications. Particular attention will be given to linking geophysics with modern hydraulic flow and solute transport modelling.
subject or unit description 6: In this unit you will apply skills learned in previous courses to a "real world" mineral exploration setting by carrying out a range of geophysical survey methods at a remote project area, and by writing an industry standard report summarising the project background, problems addressed, methods applied in the field, data processing - analysis - interpretation methodology and final outcomes.
subject or unit description 7: Introduce students to advanced techniques and exploration practice in geophysical processing and interpretation; seismic data processing, use of commercial geophysical packages (such as PROMAX, Geosoft, Encom, ER Mapper and/or Intrepid) to process and interpret geophysical data sets. Lectures will take the form of pre-laboratory sessions and cover the necessary theory for the laboratory exercises.
subject or unit description 8: Electromagnetic (EM): Basic principles; description of frequency and time domain EM systems; magnetotellurics (MT) and CSAMT, system characteristics and response forms; field configurations, modelling and interpretation techniques; applications and geoelectrical considerations.
subject or unit description 9: The main aim of the unit is to provide students with an in-depth understanding of the process of seismic data acquisition for both onshore and offshore situations. These two environments are significantly different and accordingly require implementations of specialised technologies, different acquisition geometries and strategies and even different data processing and analysis algorithms. Consequently, the course is divided into two main parts: land and marine seismic data acquisition. Land seismic lectures elaborate on the two-dimensional (2D) seismic data acquisition techniques, including survey design, selection of recording parameter and implementation of various acquisition geometries. Land data acquisition then expands into more complex three-dimensional (3D) space. Optimisation of the 3D geometry is the key to successful implementation of the reflection seismic method for exploration of oil, gas and minerals. Our department operates a state-of-the-art land seismic data acquisition equipment. The marine seismic part of the course is typically conducted by top industry scientists due to very complex and fast evolving methodologies and instrumentation utilised in marine seismic surveys. Students are fully exposed to the latest developments in the seismic data acquisition sector, including novel instrumentation and acquisition strategies for both onshore and offshore surveys.
subject or unit description 10: Seismic waves in a homogenous medium. Plane and spherical waves. Evanescent plane waves. Boundary conditions. Zeoppritz equations. Principles of Amplitude versus offset (AVO) analysis. AVO approximations. AVO classes. Seismic Anisotropy. Land seismic data processing. AVO analysis for detection of gas accumulations. Seismic Inversion for porosity mapping and hydrocarbon search.
